utterances: So tell me about this U.S.
News & World Report listing.
For people who aren't quite in the frenzy of choosing a college yet or for those who've been out for long enough, they may not know exactly what this is.
It's a ranking of schools.
There's sort of the university list and a liberal arts school list, and it uses criteria to weigh the schools.
In fact, it ranks them one through whatever, 60, 70.
What are the criteria that are most weighted by this list?
Well, you're right.
I think it's important that students and families understand what U.S.
News is and what it does.
First of all, let me just say that it provides some very interesting and useful information.
The concern we have about it and what I want people to know about it is that U.S.
News is a business.
It wants to make a profit.
And this edition of their magazine is their most profitable because, I think, because people love rankings.
They're so attractive.
It's so, you know, interesting to think well, what's number one and what's number 10 and what's number 50 and so on and so forth.

But inherently, again, if you think of the concept of match, a ranking isn't going to help you because each individual person would have their own rankings based on the kinds of things they're interested in.
You know, would you want a big school, again, do you want a small school?
Do you want a film studies major or do you want be a chemist?
You know, each one would be individual.
So what U.S.
News does is compiles rankings that are based on a bunch of factual indices.
And that comes from information that the colleges provide themselves.
Such as SAT scores, the top of the class…
That's right.
…the bottom of the class, these sorts of things that the incoming students are.
What else?
SAT scores, selectivity, student-faculty ratio, something called financial resources, something called faculty resources, graduation rate.
So they use a lot of information that would be useful to students.
And you can sort it on their Web site, which is very handy.

There are other Web sites that do that as well, which I can mention in a minute, but 25 percent of their ranking, and I think the part that makes it the most, you know, sort of, sensational when it comes out on the news stands is 25 percent of a school's ranking comes from a survey that is sent out to all college presidents, all college academic deans, and all college deans of admissions - three people at each institution.
I actually - I didn't because I - my parents were very good about not putting pressure on me in terms of the, you know, U.S.
News & World Report rankings of a school.
Whereas, those were kind of pressures that I definitely felt from the school - with SAT scores and things like that.
I'll bet they didn't have catfish.
No, I think not.
I'll just bet they didn't.
(Soundbite of laughter)
A very tired roast beef sandwich.
Yeah.
But that's the difference between running one of these long-distance trains, and you got to invest - it costs extra money, but you got the Roomette, the sleeper car.
Right.
That was my treat.
The fare, basic fare, is not too bad.
What makes it expensive is a Roomette, which is about 360 dollars for two people.
And since I was traveling alone, it was kind of a bite for me.
That includes the night's sleep and all meals.
So, it's not quite as awful as it sounds.
So, it's not quite as awful as it sounds.
No.
Nevertheless, pretty expensive.
No. When it's a couple...
Yeah.
I was surprised, though, the number of people you found who said they did it, traveled by train, because they got great deals.
Not merely great deals 'cause gas was high, great deals.
And it's last-minute travel.
It was especially noticeable at - between Chicago and New Orleans, where there are a lot more towns.
Once you get out West, there are a fewer towns, fewer stops, fewer demand.
But on these sort of short hops between towns going south, there were lots of people who'd get on at one town, say, St. Louis, and get off a few hours later, or half a day later.
And for them, several people told me it was cheaper at the last minute to do that than take the Greyhound.
And...
Which I had no idea.
Astonishing.
I didn't try it that way, yeah.
Believe me, you don't want to ride the Greyhound.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But the - you were talking about discovering the difference between transportation and travel.
Right, right.
This - if you looked at it as transportation, the airplane is always going to win, even if it's uncomfortable, and you have to pay for your own luggage.
If it's travel, which is what I would have done in Europe, you talk to people, you look out the window, you relax, then Amtrak holds up very well.
Yet, they are notorious, especially out west, for being late.
Yes, and it's not their fault, which - I feel - I sort of feel defensive about this.
I'm sort of the Amtrak cheerleader, I guess, right now.
The rails are owned by Amtrak out east, where you ride them.
So, the trains, by and large, run really well on time.
The western routes are owned, or leased, or run, anyway, by foreign - Canadian carriers, by freight railroads, and not by Amtrak itself.
So, Amtrak is supposed to have - passengers are supposed to take precedence, but if it's me or a load of food that's going out west, the food's going to win.
And obviously, the commercial rail travel has been exceptionally heavy as exports and imports increase.
Absolutely.
Yeah, much more pressure on the existing services.
Yet, did you find the passengers willing to tolerate the lateness?
They were 'til they got tired.
The shorter-haul people didn't mind.

And the people who didn't have a set schedule like mine didn't mind either, but one lady I met, she was stranded sort of with the rest of us, five hours west of - for four or five hours west of San Antonio, while three different trains, as we heard it, were moved by the same crew.
So, it got late.
She was trying to get to a high-school graduation, and she said finally her grandkid would be out of college by the time she got there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Could get frustrating.
Yeah.

Our guest is Catherine Watson, the former travel editor of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, wrote a story called ""Romance of the Rails"" for the San Francisco Chronicle, about a recent visit from her home in Minneapolis to New Mexico.
If you'd like to join the conversation, 800-989-8255.
Why do you ride the train or not?
Or you could send us an email, talk@npr.org.
Let's start with Lauren, and Lauren's calling us from Ames in Iowa.
Yes, I am.
Thank you for taking my call.
I love your show.
Thank you.
I was just calling because I, actually, my freshman year in college, was strapped for cash and couldn't get a plane ticket to see my sister out in Colorado.
And from Burlington, Iowa, out to Glenwood Springs, I saw so many things I would never see driving on the road.
Going through the mountains was just beautiful, and they have a sightseeing car that you can pretty much look up and they have windows that just cover the entire ceiling of the cars, so...
Of the domed car, yeah.
Instead of sleeping in a sleeper car, or in my seat, I actually slept under the stars.
So, it was phenomenal.
I also really loved it, and I've been trying to talk my friends into coming with me ever since, but it hasn't exactly worked.
Abby, thank you so much for talking to us once again.
Of course.
Yeah, it's - what's amazing is you see how big the country is, and you don't have to be worrying about maps or stopping for gas.
Yeah.
You just get to look.
